concept.title: Building the sample travel app
concept.shortdesc: The travel app demonstrates how to interact with the Couchbase query service. You can download the complete source code and then build and run the app. While the app runs, you can view the log of N1QL queries that it sends. The documentation for the travel app illustrates the data model and walks through the N1QL queries used to select flights.

conbody.p: The travel app is written in Node.js and incorporates the following frameworks:

The application allows users to find flights by entering airports and travel dates. For the airport entries, the app uses a N1QL query bound to an Angular typeahead directive to suggest airport names based on the first few letters entered.

section.title: Building and running the travel app
section.p: Couchbase Server and the sample travel app must be running on the same machine. To build and run the sample travel app:

ol.li: Install Couchbase Server 4.0, but do not install any sample data buckets and do not go through the setup screens or do any other setup.
Install node.js on the machine that is running Couchbase Server.

In a terminal window for the machine that is running Couchbase Server, enter the following commands: $ mkdir ~/try-cb $ git clone https://github.com/ToddGreenstein/try-cb-nodejs.git ~/try-cb $ cd ~/try-cb $ npm install $ node app.js
The command sequence creates a new directory, clones the GitHub repository that contains the travel app, installs dependencies, and starts the travel app.
The travel app runs in this terminal window. You must keep this window open so that the travel app continues running.
The app logs each query that it sends. Keep the terminal window visible when you use the app to see how the queries are formulated when you enter values in the fields.

Open a new terminal window and enter the following command: $ curl -v -X POST http://hostname:3000/api/status/provisionCB
In the URL, hostname represents the name or IP address of the computer that hosts Couchbase Server and the travel app. If you are running them on your local machine, you can use localhost for the host name.
This command sends an HTTP request to an endpoint on the travel app that loads a sample data bucket and sets up the cluster. It assumes that the cluster and the travel app are running on the same server. It also sets the user name to Administrator and the password to password.

ol.li: When you are done using the travel app, terminate the process by typing control-C.

li.p: Open a browser and navigate to http://127.0.0.1:3000.
The Find a Flight form is displayed:
In the Airport or City section, enter an airport code or city name in the From and To fields.
For example, if you enter the airport code LHR, the name Heathrow pops up, and if you enter LAX, the name Los Angeles Intl pops up.

ol.li: In the Travel Dates section, select Leave and Return dates by using the date picker that pops up when you click the date fields.

li.p: The app displays the available flights for the outbound and return legs of the trip.
